Introduction
Throughout history people have written fantastic works of science fiction so unbelievable that they in fact inspired inventors and scientists to pursue these futuristic ideas. During the 19th century, Jules Vern wrote about submarines, underwater breathing apparatuses, and journeying to the moon. The people during that time period just thought that these were fictional tales. Little did they know these stories would spawn generations of dream seekers and an era of innovation. Practically every science fiction idea has become reality through technology except for some of the most recent ones, which are closer to becoming non-fiction than we realize. Technology is advancing at a rate faster than ever before; computer speeds are doubling almost every 18 months. Like Jules Vern, Michael Crichton a science fiction writer of today, has incorporated futuristic concepts in his books. In Crichtonâ€™s book â€œPrey,â€ he uses nanotechnology theories which imply the creation of tiny machines capable of killing people in a matter of seconds. Nanotechnology is the science of building things at the tiny, atomic or molecular level to make them more precise and powerful. Nanotechnology companies developing machines at the subatomic level capable of containing and disposing of a single cell in the human body is science fiction, but for how long? 
Science fiction sources of entertainment such as the â€œSix Million Dollar Manâ€ and â€œStar Trekâ€ have characters that could be viewed as transhumanists. In the TV series the â€œSix Million Dollar Manâ€ character Steve Austin was infused with technological enhancements which give him superior capabilities above and beyond that of average humans. â€œStar Trek the next Generationâ€ had an array of technologically advanced characters ranging from a race known as the Borg who travel the galaxy assimilating other races to eyewear that allowed the blind Jordy LeForge to see. These characters could also be classified as cyborgs. A Cyborg is a human infused with technology such as robotic limbs and computer enhancements. Transhumanists are a group of people who believe that science, computers, and nanotechnology will allow them to enhance their bodiesâ€™ capabilities. Organizations are being created to support transhumanism, an approach to understanding and evaluating the possibilities for overcoming the biological limitations of humans through a technological progress.  For those companies who do not yet believe the technology is available to overcome the limitations of humans, they provide an alternative technology known as cryonics. 
Cryonics is a process of freezing a terminally ill person for period of time until there is medicine available to cure them. The use of cryonics has been implemented in numerous science fiction movies including â€œDemolition Manâ€ and â€œVanilla Skyâ€. In the movie â€œDemolition Man,â€ Silvester Staloneâ€™s character is cryonically preserved and thawed out in the future to battle an enemy from his past. â€œVanilla Skyâ€ puts a twist on cryonics where Tom Cruiseâ€™s character is disfigured and cryonically preserved with hopes that the technology will be available in the future to help him. With the use of nanotechnology, transhumanist ideals, and the process of cryonics computers will prolong life indefinitely as depicted in these works of science fiction. 

Review
Ever since the mid 1970â€™s when the term â€œNanotechnologyâ€ was first coined by Norio Taniguchi, scientists have been pursuing this field of creating materials at a nanometer scale. If you take a meter and divide it by a thousand you get a millimeter. Now take one thousandth of that and you get a micron, a thousandth of a thousandth of a meter. A nanometer is one thousandth of a micron, one billionth of a meter. Another way to look at how incredibly small a nanometer is would be to compare it to the width of a human hair. A nanometer is the width of six bonded carbon atoms, and you need about 40,000 of them to equal the width of a human hair. 
Nanotechnology is already being put to use today to create stronger, lighter and longer lasting materials. One of the substances being used is known as nanoclay which is clay from the smectite family. Smectites have a unique morphology in which they swell when exposed to water. Fortunately this feature is in the nanometer range. Nanoclay is used to form what is known as nanocomposites, which are a new class of plastics derived from a highly refined form of nanoclay that disperses in plastic resins. 
Today there are companies putting these micro materials to use in stain-repellent, clothing and metals as hard as diamond which are used to make cutting tools, drill bits, armor plates and jet engine parts. Nanoclays and nanocomposites are being used in packaging for foods and liquids to prolong shelf life. The website Nanotech-now provides current news about all aspects of nanotechnology. Nanotech-now gives instances of current nanocomposites uses. For example, Wilson Double Core tennis balls have a nanocomposite coating that keeps it bouncing twice as long as an old-style ball. Made by InMat LLC, these nanocomposites are a mix of butyl rubber, intermingled with nanoclay particles, giving the ball substantially longer shelf life. (http://nanotech-now.com/current-uses.htm).
Nanotechnologists are making predictions on how this technology will reform health related services and products. Los Alamos National Laboratory, a government funded project, predicts that nanotechnology will drastically change the industry. Within a few decades, healthcare will be revolutionized by combining nanotechnology with biotechnology to produce ingestible systems that will work its way through the body and be passed out if the patient is healthy but will notify a physician where and what type of problems the patient is experiencing. Nano-sized devices will be constructed that will be capable of removing pollutants and chemical warfare agents from the environment. (http://nanotech-now.com/predictions.htm). 
Though some nanotechnology companies are independently owned, others are going to receiving generous funding from the United States government. In 2003, congress passed a bill which allocated $3.7 billion dollars for nanotechnology research and development. An article which appeared in Lancaster New Era, a Pennsylvania newspaper in November 2003 states that, â€œWith the exception of medical and military projects, nanotechnology research is considered to be a top priority in the Bush Administration as it was in the Clinton Administration, which established the National Nanotechnology Initiative in 2000 to promote and fund researchâ€ (Poist). Scientists believe that in the next decade nanotechnology will become a $1 trillion dollar industry.
Dr. Eric Drexler, one of the first known nanotechnologists conceptualized the idea of nanobots. A Nanobot would essentially be a tiny machine capable of manufacturing small materials and perhaps one day be able to contain and dispose of a single cell. In Drexlerâ€™s book, Engines of Creation, he comments on the concept of building these microscopic machines. 
We could manufacture assembly machines much smaller even than living cells, and make materials stronger and lighter than any available today. There for, building better spacecrafts and creating tiny devices that can travel through the blood to enter and repair living cells. Which in return would allow us to heal disease, reverse the ravages of age, or make our bodies speedier or stronger than before. (Engines of creation)
Drexlerâ€™s ultimate goal is to create an â€œassembler.â€ An assembler is a tiny machine which will be able to manipulate matter at the atomic level by creating new materials; atom by atom. These machines will not only be able to make materials, but they will be capable of self-replication. Self Replication is the idea that these machines can make copies of themselves in order to speed up production or enhance their monitoring capabilities. 
The idea of nanomachines, tiny machines that would be able to carry out functions such as cancer cell disposal, fighting off viruses as they enter the body, and repairing damaged cell tissue is science fiction. Drexler's approach is different from conventional chemistry in the sense that it will be done by tiny programmable machines that place molecules with nanoscale precision. What Smalley suggests might work, is a bunch of magic fingers, which could manipulate the atoms in their chemical environment. Smalley then contradicts his own idea by saying that the fingers would be too cumbersome to fit in the giving space, and would not be able to perform the precision necessary for the atom placement. The debate continues with Smalley arguing that enzymes and ribosomes only function in water and that would limit the range of materials that could be built. In response, Drexler proposes the idea of a nanofactory where computers would be used for precise digital control, and conveyors would be used to transport materials, which would be pieced together by positioning devices to build microscopic products. He concludes with influential remarks asking other scientists to question and oppose further research of molecular manufacturing. The most prominent reason Smalley is opposed to Drexlerâ€™s work is due to the eminent consequences of molecular manufacturing. He wants the others in the science community to join him in hopes that the pursuit of Nanobot technology is halted. Smalley along with other anti-nanobot technologists believe that if these tiny robots were to go haywire then they could eventually devour the entire planet and all organic life on it.
